title: 113_s1126
content: The "Prescribe A Book Act" establishes Pediatric Early Literacy Programs under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. It includes definitions for the program. The "Prescribe A Book Act" defines an eligible entity as a nonprofit organization with demonstrated effectiveness in providing peer-to-peer training to healthcare providers in literacy promotion, delivering training curriculum in various medical education settings, offering technical assistance to healthcare facilities, and creating opportunities for local healthcare. The "Prescribe A Book Act" aims to support pediatric early literacy programs by providing technical assistance, offering discounted books to healthcare facilities, and integrating research into training curriculum for healthcare providers. The "Prescribe A Book Act" supports pediatric early literacy programs by integrating research into training curriculum for healthcare providers. The Pediatric Early Literacy Program involves healthcare providers promoting early language and literacy through reading aloud to children. The "Prescribe A Book Act" encourages healthcare providers to give children aged 6 months to 5 years new children's books during health visits and for volunteers to read aloud to children in waiting areas, promoting early literacy. The "Prescribe A Book Act" promotes reading aloud to children in healthcare facilities, demonstrating effectiveness in improving parent behavior and language skills in young children, and receiving endorsement from medical associations. The Secretary can award grants to eligible entities for Pediatric Early Literacy Programs. Eligible entities must submit an application and provide matching funds of at least 50% of the grant received. Grant funds can be used for specified purposes. An eligible entity receiving a grant for Pediatric Early Literacy Programs must enter into contracts with private nonprofit organizations or public agencies, provide training and technical assistance to contractors, and include terms determined by the Secretary for program effectiveness. Contractors are selected based on their priority to serve at-risk populations. Contractors for Pediatric Early Literacy Programs are selected based on serving at-risk children, including those from low-income families, without medical insurance, enrolled in Medicaid or CHIP, and living in rural areas. Children eligible for Pediatric Early Literacy Programs include those enrolled in State Medicaid or CHIP, living in rural areas, migrant children, and those with limited library access. The Secretary must ensure that eligible entities have arrangements with book publishers or distributors to obtain books at favorable discounts before making payments under this subpart. Eligible entities receiving grants must report annually on program effectiveness and describe each program implemented. The eligible entity receiving a grant must report annually to the Secretary on the effectiveness of the program and include a description of each program. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act to include a reporting requirement for pediatric early literacy programs.
